channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: The 47 Seconds That Saved Kamala Harris’s Political Career
item.description: Nearly 14 years ago, Kamala Harris’s opponent in the California attorney general’s race gave an answer at a little-watched debate that was frank — and fateful for the future Democratic presidential nominee.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Steve Cooley, left, then the district attorney of Los Angeles County, and Kamala Harris at a debate during their race for California attorney general in 2010.

item.title: How Kamala Harris Made Her Mark as Vice President
item.description: As President Biden’s understudy, Ms. Harris did not often get to lead on signature issues. But she found roles to play on abortion rights, gun safety and a Supreme Court appointment.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: To Undecided Voters, Harris Is Famous, but Unknown. They Want to Learn More.
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris has lit a fire among loyal Democrats. But many voters still want to know more about what she stands for.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris at Wake Tech Community College in Raleigh, N.C.

item.title: In JD Vance’s Backyard, Conspiracy Theories About Migrants and Voting Abound
item.description: A far-right plank on immigration that is rooted in a baseless theory has found purchase among Republicans and right-leaning independents in parts of Ohio.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa and Maddie McGarvey
item.media:description: Demographic and cultural changes in Ohio over the past decade have made conditions ripe for conspiracy theories about immigration to spread.

item.title: Fact-Checking Trump’s and Harris’s Attacks on Each Other’s Policies
item.description: We examine the two candidates’ criticisms of each other’s policies, promises and records.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times; Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has used a variety of attack lines on Vice President Kamala Harris, while she has sought to contrast her background as a prosecutor and attorney general with his conviction for falsifying business records.

item.title: Protesters Will Converge on Chicago. City Leaders Say They’re Prepared.
item.description: Activists plan to push for policy changes on Gaza as Democrats hold their convention. Chicago officials are confident they will avoid a repeat of the chaos that unfolded in 1968.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A security perimeter has been established around the United Center in Chicago, where the convention will take place.

item.title: For Democratic Convention Goers in Chicago, Migrants Issue Comes Into Full View
item.description: The crisis continues to play out on the city’s streets, reminding Democrats of a potential liability — border crossings — ahead of the election.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Emily Schmall and Jamie Kelter Davis
item.media:description: More than 46,000 migrants have arrived in Chicago since late 2022, the majority on buses from the southern border.

item.title: JB Pritzker Is Ready to Party at a Convention He Made Happen
item.description: An unusual and chaotic set of political circumstances forced Illinois’s billionaire governor to take the lead in securing the Democratic convention for Chicago.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Jim Vondruska for The New York Times
item.media:description: “In Illinois, Democrats deliver,” Gov. JB Pritzker said in an email when asked for his pitch for the convention.

item.title: ‘The Blind Side’ Made Him Famous. But He Has a Different Story to Tell.
item.description: The football player Michael Oher believes his early life was misrepresented by the Oscar-winning movie and the book it was based on.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sokolove
item.category: The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game (Book)
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times

item.title: Alain Delon, French Film Star, Dead at 88
item.description: The César-winning actor was an international favorite in the 1960s and ’70s, often sought after by the era’s great auteurs.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates

item.title: Where to Stream the Films of Alain Delon
item.description: A look at 10 standout films featuring the actor, who died on Sunday at 88.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Joe Biden’s Interrupted Presidency
item.description: He sought the office nearly all his life. When he finally got there, it brought out his best — and eventually his worst.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper

item.title: Six Takeaways From the Magazine’s Profile of Joe Biden
item.description: His decision to quit the race ended a remarkable chapter in American political history — and started one that may yet define his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times

item.title: Companies Hope Making Offices Like Hotels Will Lure Workers Back
item.description: Hoping to lure workers back to their desks, companies are designing “work resorts,” luxe spaces meant to compete with the comforts and versatility of their living room.
item.dc:creator: Stacey Freed
item.media:description: A man working from a co-working space at Springline in Menlo Park, Calif. Springline is a “work resort,” which means its office space designs have taken a page from boutique hotels.

item.title: Attack by Israeli Settlers in West Bank Sends Palestinians Fleeing
item.description: Residents of the village in the Israeli-occupied West Bank say one Palestinian man was killed by rampaging settlers. Israel’s military confirmed the village was attacked.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an attack on the village of Jit in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

item.title: Blinken Travels to Israel Amid Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cautioned that the negotiations were “very complex,” as the secretary of state flew to Israel to try to clinch a deal.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken landed in Tel Aviv on Sunday and was scheduled to meet in Jerusalem with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday.

item.title: Russians Fleeing Ukraine’s Advance Border Regions Rush to Kursk
item.description: In the regional capital, those who left their homes as Ukrainian forces tore into western Russia are uncertain whether they can ever return to their old lives.
item.dc:creator: Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia: What to Know
item.description: The incursion caught Russia by surprise and signified a shift in tactics for Kyiv after more than two years of war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Constant Méheut, Kim Barker, Anton Troianovski and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian men carrying a dead Russian soldier in a body bag after finding him in the rubble of a destroyed Russian border post on Monday.

item.title: Statue of John Lewis Replaces a Confederate Memorial in Georgia
item.description: The 12-foot-tall bronze statue of the civil rights leader was commissioned after Mr. Lewis died in 2020. It stands where a Confederate memorial was erected in 1908.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A statue of John Lewis, the civil rights leader, outside the DeKalb County Courthouse. It will officially be unveiled on Aug. 24.

item.title: Young Artists Rode a $712 Million Boom. Then Came the Bust.
item.description: Artists saw six-figure sales and heard promises of stardom. But with the calamitous downturn in the art market, many collectors bolted — and prices plummeted.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Julia Halperin
item.media:credit: Ysa Pérez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amani Lewis, shown with a 2024 painting, “Galatians 6:2 — the carriers,” in an artspace in Miami. Another work’s value plummeted by 90 percent. The painter said, “It feels like ‘We’re done with Amani Lewis.’”

item.title: Joe Manchin Has Some Unsolicited Advice for Kamala Harris and the Democrats
item.description: The senator from West Virginia assesses the Democratic Party and its path to victory in November.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Jonno Rattman for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Has Turned the Democratic Party Into a Pitiless Machine
item.description: The former president’s victory made it ruthlessly pragmatic.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein

item.title: Jim Foley’s Legacy Helped Change Hostage Policy
item.description: Americans held captive overseas deserve all of our help.
item.dc:creator: Diane Foley
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Harris Can Change Biden’s Policy on Israel Just by Upholding the Law
item.description: The longstanding Leahy law can — and should — change Middle East policy.
item.dc:creator: Peter Beinart
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Northwell Health Is Starting Its Own Film Studio After Starring in Documentaries
item.description: The Northwell Health system allowed filmmakers to make documentaries following its doctors, nurses and patients. It went so well, the hospital is starting a studio to make its own.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:description: On the set of Netflix’s “Lenox Hill,” set in a real-life hospital owned by Northwell Health.

item.title: Who Won Big in the Supreme Court’s Latest Term? The ‘Regulated Community.’
item.description: The phrase, used across industries to signify a shared subjugation to regulatory fiat, has been popping up after three Supreme Court decisions last month.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.category: Chevron v Natural Resources Defense Council (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: 3 More Victims of 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre Found With Gunshot Wounds
item.description: Officials are exhuming bodies to learn more about the victims of one of the worst racial attacks in U.S. history.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders
item.media:credit: Mike Simons/Tulsa World, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Crews at the Oaklawn Cemetery during an excavation of bodies from the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre. Three victims were exhumed and determined to show evidence of gunshot wounds.

item.title: Elon Musk Closes X Operations in Brazil Over Fight With Judge
item.description: The billionaire said he would shutter his social network’s Brazil operations instead of complying with a Brazilian judge’s orders to suspend accounts.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Elon Musk in Paris last year. Mr. Musk, who owns the social network X, has been in a monthslong feud with a Brazilian Supreme Court judge, Alexandre de Moraes, over what he considers censorship of conservative voices on the platform.

item.title: AJ Aquino and Dr. David Poon, Advocates Who Reunite International Couples, Get Married
item.description: AJ Aquino met Dr. David Poon while visiting Toronto from Ireland in 2017. During the pandemic, she visited him and was turned away. And so began their efforts to help other couples reunite.
item.dc:creator: Tammy LaGorce
